title: California high court to rule on gay marriage Tuesday

content: Prop. 8: Rally Win Or Lose The California Supreme Court gave notification Friday that its decision on whether or not Prop 8 will be upheld will be handed down Tuesday at 10:00 am. In response to either a win or a loss for marriage equality, rallies will be held throughout the week across the country. For people in California in particular, these rallies and events promise to draw huge crowds. Numerous websites and organizations have sprung into action in the months following election day to drive the fight toward marriage equality. For events throughout the country, visit Dayofdecision.org -- for events in California, read on. >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid85871.asp

content: Well, it looks like the CA Supreme Court ruled to uphold the ban. The 18,000 gay marriages performed last year will still remain valid, though. Wonder what will happen now...
reply: Well, it looks like the CA Supreme Court ruled to uphold the ban. The 18,000 gay marriages performed last year will still remain valid, though. Wonder what will happen now...
title: California high court to rule on gay marriage Tuesday

content: *sigh* And I was hoping to do a renewal of vows with Jenn when we go to San Francisco this summer. We'd be there will all the same people who were there when we met each other three years ago, and it would be the perfect time to get an actual marriage certificate.

content: quote: Originally posted by badbard: quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: *sigh* And I was hoping to do a renewal of vows with Jenn when we go to San Francisco this summer. We'd be there will all the same people who were there when we met each other three years ago, and it would be the perfect time to get an actual marriage certificate. Yeah, guess California doesn't need money as bad as they claim they do, 'cause they just lost out on a bunch! What a crock! In listening to the oral arguments, and reading all (groan) the paperwork, I was surprised to notice that NOBODY challenged the assertion that the change in the CA Constitution was merely one of the definition of the term "marriage". I could clearly see that it could have been argued that by "defining" in this manner 1) it had substantive legal consequences negatively effecting the excluded parties in over 1400 other legal and policy processes throughout the State, as well as in relation to the equal protection status of visitors or immigrants from other States where SSM is legal; and 2) that Prop.8 was not a mere redefinition due to it's sweeping effect through application of dependent laws, codes and subsequent policies. The majority and concurring opinions both have statements in them that seemed to me to be almost suggesting these and other avenues for further cases. Once again in my life, the heteros have relegated me and mine to the position of NI&&3% in my native land, which I have served, and to which I have contributed my time talents and resources every day of my life. P!$$ed-off doesn't even come close. New England winters are beginning to look mighty fine . . . if not Ontarian. Decision is here: -->http://www.courtinfo.ca.gov/opinions/documents/S168047.PDF

content: I see the California Gov. (Arnold S.) said Tuesday night on the Tonight Show he believes sooner or later gays will be allowed to marry in Calif. I seem to also recall him saying some time ago the thought all marriage should be 'gay'! (or is that an urban legend?)
reply: I see the California Gov. (Arnold S.) said Tuesday night on the Tonight Show he believes sooner or later gays will be allowed to marry in Calif. I seem to also recall him saying some time ago the thought all marriage should be 'gay'! (or is that an urban legend?)
title: California high court to rule on gay marriage Tuesday

content: New Prop. 8 court challenge brings former legal rivals together The California Supreme Court failed to protect gay couples' fundamental right to marry when it upheld Proposition 8, forcing same-sex couples to appeal to the federal courts to remedy the injustice, two prominent lawyers said today in announcing a lawsuit on behalf of two gay couples. Former U.S. Solicitor General Theodore Olson, a renowned conservative, and David Boies, who opposed Olson in Bush v. Gore in the 2000 fight over the presidential election, cast their collaborative effort to restore the right of gays to marry in California as a moral imperative to correct an injustice. Their suit seeks an immediate injunction on Prop. 8's ban, thereby allowing same-sex marriages to resume while the case makes its way through the federal court system. Read full article at >>> >>>http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2009/05/olson-boies-team-up-to-fight-prop-8-in-federal-court.html

Former U.S. Solicitor General Theodore Olson, a renowned conservative, and David Boies, who opposed Olson in Bush v. Their suit seeks an immediate injunction on Prop. 8's ban, thereby allowing same-sex marriages to resume while the case makes its way through the federal court system. content: All of this is just history now and behind us. What matters now is this issue will appear again on the ballot in California likely as soon as next year. I am confident the results will be different next time. >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid86512.asp >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid86545.asp >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid86423.asp >>>http://feinstein.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=NewsRoom.PressReleases&ContentRecord_id=7e2b4e9f-5056-8059-767c-01285999398b&Region_id=&Issue_id=
